segment.source: Gathering Information about Your Active Directory Deployment (Windows 10)
segment.target: Gathering Information about Your Active Directory Deployment (Windows 10)

segment.source: Gathering Information about Your Active Directory Deployment
segment.target: Gathering Information about Your Active Directory Deployment

segment.source: Gathering Information about Your Active Directory Deployment
segment.target: Gathering Information about Your Active Directory Deployment

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: Active Directory is another important item about which you must gather information.
segment.target: Active Directory is another important item about which you must gather information.

segment.source: You must understand the forest structure.
segment.target: You must understand the forest structure.

segment.source: This includes domain layout, organizational unit (OU) architecture, and site topology.
segment.target: This includes domain layout, organizational unit (OU) architecture, and site topology.

segment.source: This information makes it possible to know where devices are currently placed, their configuration, and the impact of changes to Active Directory that result from implementing Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.
segment.target: This information makes it possible to know where devices are currently placed, their configuration, and the impact of changes to Active Directory that result from implementing Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.

segment.source: Review the following list for information needed:
segment.target: Review the following list for information needed:

segment.source: Names and number of forests.
segment.target: Names and number of forests.

segment.source: The forest (not the domain) is the security boundary in an Active Directory implementation.
segment.target: The forest (not the domain) is the security boundary in an Active Directory implementation.

segment.source: You must understand the current Active Directory architecture to determine the most effective strategy for deploying your firewall and connection security rules using Group Policy.
segment.target: You must understand the current Active Directory architecture to determine the most effective strategy for deploying your firewall and connection security rules using Group Policy.

segment.source: It also enables you to understand which devices can be isolated and how best to accomplish the required degree of isolation.
segment.target: It also enables you to understand which devices can be isolated and how best to accomplish the required degree of isolation.

segment.source: Names and number of domains.
segment.target: Names and number of domains.

segment.source: Authentication in server and domain isolation uses the IKE negotiation process with the Kerberos V5 protocol.
segment.target: Authentication in server and domain isolation uses the IKE negotiation process with the Kerberos V5 protocol.

segment.source: This protocol assumes that devices are domain members.
segment.target: This protocol assumes that devices are domain members.

segment.source: Number and types of trusts.
segment.target: Number and types of trusts.

segment.source: Trusts affect the logical boundaries of domain isolation and define whether IKE negotiation can occur between devices in different Active Directory domains.
segment.target: Trusts affect the logical boundaries of domain isolation and define whether IKE negotiation can occur between devices in different Active Directory domains.

segment.source: Names and number of sites.
segment.target: Names and number of sites.

segment.source: Site architecture is usually aligned with the network topology.
segment.target: Site architecture is usually aligned with the network topology.

segment.source: Understanding how sites are defined in Active Directory will help provide insight into replication and other details.
segment.target: Understanding how sites are defined in Active Directory will help provide insight into replication and other details.

segment.source: Site architecture can provide a better understanding of the current Active Directory deployment.
segment.target: Site architecture can provide a better understanding of the current Active Directory deployment.

segment.source: OU structure.
segment.target: OU structure.

segment.source: OUs are logical constructs and can therefore be molded to fit many different requirements and goals.
segment.target: OUs are logical constructs and can therefore be molded to fit many different requirements and goals.

segment.source: The OU structure is an ideal place to examine how Group Policy is currently used and how the OUs are laid out.
segment.target: The OU structure is an ideal place to examine how Group Policy is currently used and how the OUs are laid out.

segment.source: You do not have to redesign an already implemented OU structure in order to effectively deploy firewall and connection security policy, but an understanding of the structure helps you know what WMI or group filtering is required to apply each GPO to the correct devices.
segment.target: You do not have to redesign an already implemented OU structure in order to effectively deploy firewall and connection security policy, but an understanding of the structure helps you know what WMI or group filtering is required to apply each GPO to the correct devices.

segment.source: Existing IPsec policy.
segment.target: Existing IPsec policy.

segment.source: Because this project culminates in the implementation of IPsec policy, you must understand how the network currently uses IPsec (if at all).
segment.target: Because this project culminates in the implementation of IPsec policy, you must understand how the network currently uses IPsec (if at all).

segment.source: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security connection security rules for versions of Windows prior to Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008 are not compatible with earlier versions of Windows.
segment.target: Windows Firewall with Advanced Security connection security rules for versions of Windows prior to Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008 are not compatible with earlier versions of Windows.

segment.source: If you already have IPsec policies deployed to devices running Windows XP and Windows Server 2003 in your organization, you must ensure that the new IPsec policies you deploy enable devices using either the old or new IPsec policies to communicate with each other.
segment.target: If you already have IPsec policies deployed to devices running Windows XP and Windows Server 2003 in your organization, you must ensure that the new IPsec policies you deploy enable devices using either the old or new IPsec policies to communicate with each other.
